natural solution: \[\mathbf{A}^4 = \mathbf{A}^2 \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Since $\mathbf{A}^4$ is a diagonal matrix, any power of $\mathbf{A}^4$ is

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,0,0], [0,0,-1], [0,1,0]])"
shows  "matrix_pow A 95 = matrix([[0,0,0], [0,0,1], [0,-1,0]])"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Compute $\mathbf{A}^{95}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\mathbf{A}^4 = \mathbf{A}^2 \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Since $\mathbf{A}^4$ is a diagonal matrix, any power of $\mathbf{A}^4$ is
 \begin{align} (\mathbf{A}^4)^{k} = \begin{pmatrix} 0^k & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1^k & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1^k \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A}^4. \end{align}Hence, \begin{align}
 \mathbf{A}^{95} &= (\mathbf{A}^4)^{23} \mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A}^4 \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,0,0], [0,0,-1], [0,1,0]])"
shows  "matrix_pow A 95 = matrix([[0,0,0], [0,0,1], [0,-1,0]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Compute $\mathbf{A}^{95}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\mathbf{A}^4 = \mathbf{A}^2 \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Since $\mathbf{A}^4$ is a diagonal matrix, any power of $\mathbf{A}^4$ is
 \begin{align} (\mathbf{A}^4)^{k} = \begin{pmatrix} 0^k & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1^k & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1^k \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A}^4. \end{align}Hence, \begin{align}
 \mathbf{A}^{95} &= (\mathbf{A}^4)^{23} \mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A}^4 \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}
 \end{align}
 *)

Calculate the 95th power of the 3x3 matrix A, where A is defined as:

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "int^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0, 0, 0], [0, 0, -1], [0, 1, 0]])"
shows  "matrix_pow A 95 = matrix([[0, 0, 0], [0, 0, 1], [0, -1, 0]])"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Compute $\mathbf{A}^{95}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\mathbf{A}^4 = \mathbf{A}^2 \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Since $\mathbf{A}^4$ is a diagonal matrix, any power of $\mathbf{A}^4$ is
 \begin{align} (\mathbf{A}^4)^{k} = \begin{pmatrix} 0^k & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1^k & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1^k \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A}^4. \end{align}Hence, \begin{align}
 \mathbf{A}^{95} &= (\mathbf{A}^4)^{23} \mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A}^4 \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}
 \end{align}
 *)

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and A_95 :: "real^3^3"
defines "A \<equiv> matrix([[0,0,0],[0,0,-1],[0,1,0]])"
and "A_95 \<equiv> A ^^ 95"
shows  "A_95 = matrix([[0,0,0],[0,0,1],[0,-1,0]])"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Compute $\mathbf{A}^{95}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\mathbf{A}^4 = \mathbf{A}^2 \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Since $\mathbf{A}^4$ is a diagonal matrix, any power of $\mathbf{A}^4$ is
 \begin{align} (\mathbf{A}^4)^{k} = \begin{pmatrix} 0^k & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1^k & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1^k \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A}^4. \end{align}Hence, \begin{align}
 \mathbf{A}^{95} &= (\mathbf{A}^4)^{23} \mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A}^4 \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}
 \end{align}
 *)

 \mathbf{A}^{95} &= (\mathbf{A}^4)^{23} \mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A}^4 \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,0,0],[0,0,-1],[0,1,0]])"
and h1 : "A ^^ 95 = matrix([[0,0,0],[0,0,1],[0,-1,0]])"
shows  "A ^^ 95 = matrix([[0,0,0],[0,0,1],[0,-1,0]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem:
Given a 3x3 matrix A with its elements defined as follows:

Row 1: [0, 0, 0]
Row 2: [0, 0, -1]
Row 3: [0, 1, 0]

If the 95th power of matrix A is:

Row 1: [0, 0, 0]
Row 2: [0, 0, 1]
Row 3: [0, -1, 0]

Then, confirm that the 95th power of matrix A is:

Row 1: [0, 0, 0]
Row 2: [0, 0, 1]
Row 3: [0, -1, 0]

a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Compute $\mathbf{A}^{95}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\mathbf{A}^4 = \mathbf{A}^2 \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Since $\mathbf{A}^4$ is a diagonal matrix, any power of $\mathbf{A}^4$ is
 \begin{align} (\mathbf{A}^4)^{k} = \begin{pmatrix} 0^k & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1^k & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1^k \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{A}^4. \end{align}Hence, \begin{align}
 \mathbf{A}^{95} &= (\mathbf{A}^4)^{23} \mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A}^4 \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0, 0, 0], [0, 0, -1], [0, 1, 0]])"
shows  "(A ^ 95) = matrix([[0, 0, 0], [0, 0, 1], [0, -1, 0]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
Calculate the 95th power of the matrix 
\[
\begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -1 \\
0 & 1 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
\]
The final result should be 
\[
\begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & -1 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
\]
